Remembering Smita Patil, The Shining Star Of ‘70s Who Changed The Way People Looked At Hindi Film Heroines

Remembering Smita Patil, The Shining Star Of ‘70s Who Changed The Way People Looked At Hindi Film Heroines

If you remember the cinema of the ’70s and ‘80s, it was all about melodrama, some romance, vengeance, struggles, joys as well as sorrows. In that time, if there was once actress who changed the way people looked at the Hindi movie heroines, it was Smita Patil, who was hailed as the brightest star of that time.

In the male dominated cinema, she established herself as a stellar performer and played roles that were empowering. In her short career, she gave Indian cinema many great complex performances and left behind a treasure of cinematic brilliance.

Some of her best works include path-breaking movies that include Manthan (1976), Bhumika (1977), Aakrosh (1980), Chakra (1981, Arth (1982) and Mirch Masala (1985) among others.

She started her career as a TV announcer and gradually became an established actress.

She was also the youngest film star to be honoured with Padma Shri award in 1985. But she died too early.

Smita Patil died two weeks she was giving birth to her son Prateik Babbar at the age of 31. Had she been alive today, she would 64 years old.

Remembering her, son Prateik Babbar posted a tribute on social media calling her the gorgeous lady. “Happy birthday to my gorgeous lady,” he wrote in the caption of one of the pictures.

The Ekk Deewana Tha actor also shared a still of Smita from the song Tohfa Kabool from the 1983 movie Ghungroo."’Do not breathe.. what people will think’ -- smita patil (1955-1986) rest in power," he wrote alongside the image.

Smita Patil appeared in over 80 Hindi, Marathi and Malayalam films in a career that spanned just over a decade. During her acting journey, she received two National Film Awards.

The actress was married to actor Raj Babbar. She died on Dec 13, 1986 at the age of 31 due to childbirth complications. Over 10 of her films were released after her death.
